page.title: 15Snibston
page.content: { Snibston}is a hamlet consisting of four houses, a farm with a moated house, a church and a school built in 1906 as a{County School}catering for eighty pupils between the ages of five and fourteen. The church of{St.Mary's built in the twelfth century was originally tied to the parish of Packington, but in 1910 was separated. In the last fifteen years several farms have disappeared and their buildings have been demolished for either open cast workings or for the area to be used as a waste dump for the now closed{Snibstone Mine. The name{Snibston}derives from the snipe which used to nest near the stream at the foot of Standard Hill, so named because an unknown standard was raised on the site at the time of the{Battle of Bosworth, 1485.}Soldiers bodies were found in the churchyard.
